creator: lars@trieloff.net
bruyeron@fullsix.com
text:
Are the dependencies to xerces, fop and rhino required (in batik-dom,
batik-transcoder and batik-script)?
fop for example is only needed in certain use-cases, and on JDK6 rhino is
included in the JDK.

Could they be made optional?

creator: cam@apache.org
text:
Thanks for making those, Lars.  Did you investigate the actual dependencies
between the jars, or use those that were specified in the 1.6 version of the
poms?  Unfortunately I haven't got around to getting a definitive list of
dependencies yet.

If you're assuming a recent JRE, then yes, I think some of those dependencies
can be dropped.  JRE 1.4 has an appropriate JAXP XML parser bundled, IIRC, so
Xerces wouldn't be needed there.  I'm not sure if the bundled pdf-transcoder.jar
differs much from the standard FOP distribution.  As for Rhino, currently a more
recent version than the one included with JRE 1.6 is required (including a patch
that has not yet gone into Rhino's CVS).

creator: lars@trieloff.net
text:
(In reply to comment #18)
> Did you investigate the actual dependencies
> between the jars, or use those that were specified in the 1.6 version of the

I've reviewed the existing POMs and updated them when neccessary to the dependency description at 
http://xmlgraphics.apache.org/batik/install.html

I don't think excluding dependencies like Xerces conditionally is neccessary, as the libraries requiring Batik 
can exclude them in their build depending on their own build profiles.

creator: jake.landis@cerner.com
text:
FYI, If others run into this....The SPI runtime dependencies are not listed in the POM (at least for the transcoder project http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/xmlgraphics/batik-transcoder/1.7/batik-transcoder-1.7.pom).  For example this dependency is a runtime depedency for the transcoder project:
		<dependency> 
			<groupId>org.apache.xmlgraphics</groupId>
			<artifactId>batik-codec</artifactId>
			<version>1.7</version>
			<scope>runtime</scope>
		</dependency>	

Not sure if leaving out the SPI runtime dependencies from the POM is a bug or if it is by design....but can result in this error if you dont have a service provider defined on the class path for org.apache.batik.ext.awt.image.spi.ImageWriter (batik-codec contains the default service provider):

org.apache.batik.transcoder.TranscoderException: null
Enclosed Exception:
Could not write PNG file because no WriteAdapter is availble
	at org.apache.batik.transcoder.image.ImageTranscoder.transcode(ImageTranscoder.java:132)
	at org.apache.batik.transcoder.XMLAbstractTranscoder.transcode(XMLAbstractTranscoder.java:142)
	at org.apache.batik.transcoder.SVGAbstractTranscoder.transcode(SVGAbstractTranscoder.java:156)
So, since ImageWriter lives in batik-awt-util, should it be the one that depends on batik-codec?
creator: cam@apache.org
jake.landis@cerner.com
text: I am not terribly familiar with the code in this project, but generally who ever has the first order dependency would define the runtime dependency.  Alternatively, the expected consumable jars could define the runtime dependencies, but that is often difficult determine upfront. Also to keep in mind (at least in my experience), SPI runtime dependencies do not show up correctly in  mvn dependency:analyze.
